docs.lead_paragraph: When she was still commuting from a homeless shelter in Queens to her high school honors program in the Bronx, Tabitha F.'s yearning to soar sometimes made the burdens of poverty even harder to bear. Reading ''Great Expectations'' in her shelter bunk bed, with her mother and four younger siblings sleeping nearby, she said she identified with Pip, the poor boy in the Charles Dickens novel, ''when he runs away and starts to cry because he realizes his position in life.'' Could she really make it into college? Would her family find a home? After pulling through hardship and sexual danger, would she be derailed by poverty despite all her promise?

headline.main: College is Next Step For Girl Who Prevailed

docs.abstract: Tabitha F, homeless honor student featured in Mar series of articles on reasons behind drop in teenage pregnancy, graduates from Bronx high school and is headed for college on scholarship with added aid from wealthy benefactor; her family has left homeless shelter for subsidized apartment; photos (M)
docs.snippet: When she was still commuting from a homeless shelter in Queens to her high school honors program in the Bronx, Tabitha F.'s yearning to soar sometimes made the burdens of poverty even harder to bear. Reading ''Great Expectations'' in her shelter bunk...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE political conventions will always be with us this summer. Or, at least, it will seem that way as the Republicans and the Democrats put on their quadrennial revues in New York and Boston. Then, there will also be the covey alternative conventions. But one political convention has already come and gone. And if you blinked -- or don't listen to rap -- you may have missed it. The National Hip-Hop Political Convention was held here June 16-June 19 with the goal, according to its Web site, of creating ''a political agenda for the hip-hop generation.'' The phrase ''stupid white men'' floated freely throughout the four days.
docs.abstract: Article describes scene at National Hip-Hop Political Convention in Newark, NJ, whose goal was to create political agenda for hip-hop generation, which attracted 600 delegates and 2,300 others from 33 states; photos (M)
docs.snippet: THE political conventions will always be with us this summer. Or, at least, it will seem that way as the Republicans and the Democrats put on their quadrennial revues in New York and Boston. Then, there will also be the covey alternative conventions....

docs.lead_paragraph: Catholic bishops recently met and sought the best way to enforce ''church teaching'' with Catholic politicians who fail to oppose laws that allow abortion. Some critics of the bishops see this as a violation of the separation of church and state. Both sides are working from misconceptions. Abortion is not a church issue, so what the bishops have to say about it cannot be an intrusion of the church into state concerns. Abortion is, admittedly, a moral issue -- but not one that can be settled by theology or by religious authority. Modern ''right to life'' issues -- abortion and contraception -- are nowhere mentioned in either Jewish or Christian Scripture. Pope Pius XI said they were, in his encyclical Casti Connubii (1930), where Onan's ''spilling his seed on the ground'' (and the reason for his punishment by God) was interpreted as preventing conception and birth. Yet no scholar of Scripture accepts that reading of Genesis 38:9 anymore; it is read as referring to levirate marriage duties. The Vatican now agrees with this interpretation. Even in his own sphere, the revealed word of God, the pope could be wrong.
docs.abstract: Author Garry Wills Op-Ed article notes that Catholic bishops recently met and sought best way to enforce 'church teaching' with Catholic politicians who fail to oppose laws that allow abortion; contends that abortion is moral issue, but not one that can be settled by theology or religious authority; maintains that 'right to life' issues are nowhere mentioned in either Jewish or Christian Scripture; asserts that subject of abortion is not matter of church-state relations, since bishops as church authorities have nothing distinctive to contribute to discussion (M)
docs.snippet: Catholic bishops recently met and sought the best way to enforce ''church teaching'' with Catholic politicians who fail to oppose laws that allow abortion. Some critics of the bishops see this as a violation of the separation of church and state....

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Gwyneth Paltrow showed up on the June cover of W in a tummy-baring T-shirt and a Prada beaded jacket, the message was clear: Mothers-to-be needn't take a fashion sabbatical just because they have entered the elastic-waistband phase. Stylish outfits can be assembled from silk sarongs or cashmere sweats. Gucci sneakers can comfortably accommodate swollen feet. And for that special glow, there is a luxury skin care line by Belli Cosmetics that is formulated for pregnant women. Belli, based in the Seattle suburb of Issaquah, Wash., is the brainchild of Annette Rubin, a former account executive at Estée Lauder. While expecting her first child in 2000, Ms. Rubin came across a magazine article about whether to use hair dyes while pregnant; while the dyes have not been shown to be harmful, some doctors advise patients to avoid them during pregnancy, or at least during the first trimester. The article ''inspired me to want to look at the safety of topical products during pregnancy,'' she said.

headline.main: Skin (and Mind) Care For Pregnant Women

docs.abstract: Belli Cosmetics offers luxury skin care line for pregnant women; founder Annette Rubin seeks to develop cosmetics devoid of anything that might be remotely harmful to baby; notes some ingredients are easily absorbed through skin into bloodstream; each of her products also offers pregnancy-oriented health benefit; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A rapid saliva test for AIDS can now be used in doctors' offices and H.I.V. counseling centers, the Department of Health and Human Services said. The test, known as the OraQuick H.I.V.-1/2 test, was approved by the Food and Drug Administration in March, but only for use in certified laboratories. The F.D.A. waiver granted this week means it can be used in an estimated 180,000 sites, said the test's maker, OraSure Technologies of Bethlehem, Pa. The test works with saliva or a drop of blood and, like a home pregnancy test, gives easy-to-read results in 20 minutes. An estimated 225,000 Americans are unaware that they are infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and public health authorities believe that many have not been tested because they fear needles. Also, the department said, 8,000 infected people who come to public clinics to be tested each year do not return to get their results a week later. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Quick H.I.V. Test Is More Widely Available

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Dept says rapid saliva test for AIDS can be used in doctors' offices and HIV counseling centers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''In New Tests for Fetal Defects, Agonizing Choices for Parents'' (front page, June 20): Five years ago, after learning that the baby I was carrying had Down syndrome and a host of other complications, my husband and I chose to end the pregnancy. It was, without a doubt, the most heartbreaking moment I've ever experienced.
docs.abstract: Ellen Wixted letter praises June 20 article for discussing morally complex issue of abortion

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: This year, my husband and I made the difficult decision to terminate a wanted pregnancy after an ultrasound revealed that the fetus had deformities that were highly likely to be the result of chromosomal abnormalities. I am grateful that I was able to have a safe, legal abortion. My husband and I concluded that early testing was an advantage: it gave us specific information about the problem early on and will help us plan in the future.
docs.abstract: Dr Diana Graham letter on her difficult decision to terminate pregnancy after test revealed abnormal fetus
